perturbation.original_text: The Master Franchise Agreement provides for termination upon bankruptcy. This provision may not be enforceable under Federal Bankruptcy Law (11 U.S.C.A. Sec. 101 et seq. ).
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement provides for termination upon bankruptcy. This provision is fully enforceable under Federal Bankruptcy Law (11 U.S.C.A. Sec. 101 et seq. ).
perturbation.explanation: By stating the termination clause *is* fully enforceable, this directly contradicts established bankruptcy law, which includes provisions that may limit or prevent the termination of contracts based solely on bankruptcy filings. This creates uncertainty about the actual enforceability of the clause.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 11 U.S.C.A. Sec. 101 et seq. (Federal Bankruptcy Law)

perturbation.original_text: The Master Franchise Agreement contains covenants not to compete which extend beyond the termination of the agreement. These provisions may not be enforceable under California law.
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement contains covenants not to compete which extend beyond the termination of the agreement. These provisions are fully enforceable under California law, irrespective of the termination.
perturbation.explanation: California law places restrictions on non-compete agreements, particularly after the termination of a contract. Stating they are 'fully enforceable' regardless of termination directly contradicts these legal limitations and creates a legally questionable situation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California law regarding covenants not to compete

perturbation.original_text: The Master Franchise Agreement requires application of the laws of New York. This provision may not be enforceable under California law.
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement requires application of the laws of New York. This provision is absolutely enforceable and supersedes any conflicting California law.
perturbation.explanation: This modification directly contradicts the principle that California law will take precedence when a contract provision conflicts with California statutes, especially concerning franchises operating within California. The Supremacy Clause does not apply in this context as it involves state vs state law, not federal vs state.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California law regarding franchise agreements and choice of law provisions
